<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Fmckinsey%20health%20institute%2Four%20insights%2Fbetter%20health%20among%20middle%20eastern%20employees%20can%20start%20with%20awareness%2Fbetter-health-among-middle-eastern-employees-can-start-with-awareness-vf.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="better-health-among-middle-eastern-employees-can-start-with-awareness-vf" data-layer-report-name="better-health-among-middle-eastern-employees-can-start-with-awareness-vf>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (13 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Previous McKinsey research</strong> has shown that for the past century or more, improvements in health have not only delivered immense social benefits<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c85fd36d-da4e-4e12-a9a3-ecedddfded05"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c85fd36d-da4e-4e12-a9a3-ecedddfded05" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/mhi/our-insights/adding-years-to-life-and-life-to-years">Adding years to life and life to years</a></em>, McKinsey, March 29, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> but also served as a powerful catalyst for economic growth by expanding the labor force and boosting productivity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bc9c7ab3-7144-4f13-a10e-0e422e98b4c7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bc9c7ab3-7144-4f13-a10e-0e422e98b4c7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/prioritizing-health-a-prescription-for-prosperity">Prioritizing health: A prescription for prosperity</a>, McKinsey Global Institute, July 8, 2020. </span></span></span></a></span> When employers invest in the health and well-being of their workforce, they have often made gains in productivity and reduced attrition.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="91a13162-6927-4553-a6a1-437c4f80a083"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="91a13162-6927-4553-a6a1-437c4f80a083" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Andrew J. Oswald et al., Happiness and productivity, <em>Journal of Labor Economics</em>, October 2015, Volume 33, Number 4.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>Countries in the Middle East and around the globe are increasingly embracing a modern definition of health that encompasses not just the absence of physical illness but an all-encompassing state of equilibrium between a persons internal and external environments. This broader definition includes four dimensions: physical, mental, social, and spiritual health.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ba80de1d-d458-4598-9ccb-aff28ae3c4d6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ba80de1d-d458-4598-9ccb-aff28ae3c4d6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><em><a href="/mhi/our-insights/adding-years-to-life-and-life-to-years">Adding years to life and life to years</a></em></em>, March 29, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the survey and what we measured</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>The McKinsey Health Institute</strong> conducted a survey in four GCC countries in August and September 2022. This survey involved more than four thousand employees in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, and Qatar.</p>
<p>We assessed a range of health outcomes (mental, physical, social, and spiritual), business outcomes (with a focus on intent to leave), and workplace factors (with a strong focus on toxic workplace behaviors) in our survey.</p>
<p>Health outcomes assessed in our survey included:</p>
<p><em><strong>Mental health: </strong>An employees cognitive, behavioral, and emotional state of being. Mental health is needed for an individual to understand and interact with the world through memory and language. Mental health allows us to experience joy, direct anger, limit harmful, impulsive behavior, and avoid serious depressive episodes. Mentally healthy individuals have the resilience to cope with normal stresses and adverse events while maintaining a positive and realistic sense of self.</em><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b31a9f0e-133a-4277-95bc-908ad83754e1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b31a9f0e-133a-4277-95bc-908ad83754e1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Silvana Galderisi et al., Toward a new definition of mental health, <em>World Psychiatry</em>, June 2015, Volume 14, Number 2; Vikram Patel, The Lancet commission on global mental health and sustainable development, <em>Lancet</em>, October 2018, Volume 392, Number 10157; <em>Adding years to life and life to years</em>, March 29, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Within this survey, we looked at four subfacets:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Burnout symptoms:</em> An employees experience of extreme tiredness, reduced ability to regulate cognitive and emotional processes, and mental distancing (Burnout Assessment Tool).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="27d0c4e9-7004-4094-a199-c42f0d9c3af4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="27d0c4e9-7004-4094-a199-c42f0d9c3af4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Wilmar Schaufeli, Hans De Witte, and Steffie Desart, <em>User Manual  Burnout Assessment Tool (BAT)  Version 2.0</em>, KU Leuven, Belgium, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Distress:</em> An employee experiencing a negative stress response, often involving negative affect and physiological reactivity (4DSQ Distress Screener).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fe842014-c97a-4f67-8fec-4851db933e4a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fe842014-c97a-4f67-8fec-4851db933e4a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Johannes Anema et al., Validation study of a distress screener, <em>Journal of Occupational Rehabilitation</em>, April 2009, Volume 19, Issue 3.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Depression symptoms: </em>An employee having little interest or pleasure in doing things, and feeling down, depressed, or hopeless (PHQ-2 Screener).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="67313ae4-08c6-4ea9-908d-a230bb61689f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="67313ae4-08c6-4ea9-908d-a230bb61689f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kurt Kroenke et al., The patient health questionnaire-2: Validity of a two-item depression screener, <em>Medical Care</em>, November 2003, Volume 41, Issue 11; Simon Gilbody et al., Screening for depression in medical settings with the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ): A diagnostic meta-analysis, <em>Journal of General Internal Medicine</em>, Volume 22, Issue 11.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Anxiety symptoms:</em> An employees feelings of nervousness, anxiousness, or being on edge, and not being able to stop or control worrying (GAD-2 Screener).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ad093771-f581-4907-8366-521db1f08a6e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ad093771-f581-4907-8366-521db1f08a6e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Amit Sapra et al., Using generalized anxiety disorder-2 (GAD-2) and GAD-7 in a primary care setting, <em>Cureus</em>, May 2020, Volume 12, Issue 5.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ol>
<p><em><strong>Physical health: </strong>The extent to which an employee can competently perform physical tasks and activities without substantial discomfort. It includes the capacity to move through the environment in which one lives with confidence and independence and to control ones interactions with the physical world via fine-motor control. Employees with good physical health have sharp sensory capacities with keen senses of touch, vision, hearing, taste, and smell. Physically healthy employees are full of energy and vitality, free from the twin scourges of debilitating pain or fatigue, as per the World Health Organization (WHO).</em><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="15ccda8e-c0d8-4df9-8895-3fccf99b659e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="15ccda8e-c0d8-4df9-8895-3fccf99b659e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The WHO quality of life (WHOQOL) - Brief, 2012 revision, WHO, 2012. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In this survey, we used a self-developed tool modifying questions from the WHOs 2012 quality of life assessment, looking at:<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6601fb02-de6f-42f8-b332-8e7885ca66ce"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6601fb02-de6f-42f8-b332-8e7885ca66ce" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The WHO quality of life (WHOQOL) - Brief, 2012 revision, WHO, 2012. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<ol>
    <li>if the stress from respondents jobs cause them to engage in unhealthy behaviors (for example, inadequate nutrition, lack of physical activity, lack of sleep)</li>
    <li>if respondents are self-reporting physical symptoms (experiencing physical pain that is preventing them from doing what they need to do at work)</li>
</ol>
<p><em><strong>Social health: </strong>Represents an employees ability to build healthy, nurturing, genuine, and supportive relationships. Employees in good social health have the capacity to form meaningful connections with others, to both receive and provide social support. Social health gives employees a strong sense of belonging to a community.</em><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1412dd85-807c-4e51-bef6-4906b892da2b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1412dd85-807c-4e51-bef6-4906b892da2b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Linda J. Waite, Social well-being and health in the older population: Moving beyond social relationships, <em>Future Directions for the Demography of Aging: Proceedings of a Workshop</em>, Washington, DC: National Academies Press, 2018; Corey Lee M. Keyes, Social well-being, <em>Social Psychology Quarterly</em>, June 1998, Volume 61, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In this survey, we used a self-developed tool modifying questions from the WHOs 2012 quality of life assessment, looking at a range of social factors (including personal relationships, participating in group activities, time spent on nonwork activities and important people in their life).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a369dac3-59b0-4d88-bbd7-4c7353e369c8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a369dac3-59b0-4d88-bbd7-4c7353e369c8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The WHO quality of life (WHOQOL), 2012. </span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p><em><strong>Spiritual health:</strong> Enables people to integrate meaning in their lives. Spiritually healthy people have a strong sense of purpose, belonging, or identity, which can correlate to better health.</em><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="813d30b9-8b03-4d13-b8e8-9aacffc720b1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="813d30b9-8b03-4d13-b8e8-9aacffc720b1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Eric S. Kim et al., Purpose in life and reduced stroke in older adults: The health and retirement study, <em>Journal of Psychosomatic Research</em>, January 22, 2013, Volume 74, Issue 5; Patrick L. Hill, Grant W. Edmonds, and Sarah E. Hampson, A purposeful lifestyle is a healthful lifestyle: Linking sense of purpose to self-rated health through multiple health behaviors, <em>Journal of Healthy Psychology</em>, 2019, Volume 24, Issue 10.</span></span></span></a></span><em>They feel a broad sense of connection to something larger than themselves, whether to a community, a calling, or a form of divinity. Spiritual health helps people feel rooted and mindful in the present moment.</em><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="26de7743-8ccc-4e55-b916-3b1f3ffa4702"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="26de7743-8ccc-4e55-b916-3b1f3ffa4702" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">John Fisher, Development and application of a spiritual well-being questionnaire called SHALOM, Religions, 2010. </span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>In this survey, we used a self-developed tool modifying questions from Spiritual Health and Life Orientation Measure, 2010, and the Work and Meaning Inventory, 2012, looking at a range of spiritual factors (including sense of fulfilling a greater purpose, living in harmony, and feeling energized by work).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="12851bdd-2a1a-4cfa-85f8-6fd2a3c46d9a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="12851bdd-2a1a-4cfa-85f8-6fd2a3c46d9a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">John Fisher, Development and application of a spiritual well-being questionnaire called SHALOM, Religions, 2010. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Work-related outcomes and factors assessed in our survey included:</p>
<p><em><strong>Intent to leave:</strong> In this survey, we used a self-developed tool to assess an employees desire to leave the organization in which they are currently employed in the next three to six months.</em></p>
<p><em><strong>Toxic workplace behavior: </strong>In this survey, we used a self-developed tool to assess an employees experience of interpersonal behavior that leads them to feel unvalued, belittled, or unsafe, such as unfair or demeaning treatment, noninclusive behavior, sabotaging, cutthroat competition, abusive management, and unethical behavior from leaders or coworkers.</em></p>
<p>The analysis of share of respondents reporting at least one mental-health challenge was determined by aggregating respondents reporting having a mental-health diagnosis, now or in the past; reporting to have sought or considered treatment for a mental-health condition; or having listed at least one of the following: symptoms of anxiety, burnout, depression, or distress.</p>
<p><strong>Consideration of cross-country surveys</strong></p>
<p>As cited in previous global pieces about health, such as <a href="/mhi/our-insights/in-sickness-and-in-health-how-health-is-perceived-around-the-world">In sickness and in health: How health is perceived around the world</a>, a range of cultural and methodological factors can influence respondents answers to survey questions. These factors include, but are not limited to, language and word association, number ranges, comprehension issues, and attitudes toward taking surveys. It is important to note that comparisons between respondents in different countries are not only due to differences in attitudes and/or behaviors between respondents but also reflect response styles that are specific to cultural and geographic locations. Any insights drawn from cross-country comparisons should be interpreted with consideration of these multiple influences to survey responses.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In early fall 2022, the McKinsey Health Institute surveyed more than four thousand employees in four Middle Eastern countries that are part of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC)Kuwait, United Arab Emirates (UAE), Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, and Qatarto understand the state of employee health in the region (see sidebar About the survey and what we measured). </p>
<p>This article summarizes what our respondents told us about the state of their health as they saw it, namely, that:</p>
<!-- -->
<ul>
    <li>Two-thirds of GCC respondents reported symptoms of poor mental health and well-being, or had a mental-health condition diagnosis.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="067a41a9-3a44-4b69-a902-a68de8c97033"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="067a41a9-3a44-4b69-a902-a68de8c97033" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Responses include reporting having a mental-health or substance-use diagnosis now or in the past; having sought or considered treatment for a mental-health or substance-use condition; or having listed at least one of the following: high symptoms of anxiety, burnout, depression, or distress.</span></span></span></a></span> </li>
    <li>One in three GCC respondents reported burnout symptoms. Many also reported struggles with physical health conditions, but better social and spiritual health, with different patterns among demographic groups. </li>
    <li>Three-quarters of GCC respondents reported being happy at work, which appeared to be correlated with employees listing a sense of purpose in their work and in their relationships at work.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some targeted actions by GCC countries point to growing recognition of the importance of promoting employee health and well-being. For example, the UAE has been an early adopter in integrating employee health and well-being into its governmental agenda by setting up the National Program for Happiness and Wellbeing.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="025c878e-9c07-49e1-ab70-36bd79f21a60"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="025c878e-9c07-49e1-ab70-36bd79f21a60" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">National Programme for Happiness and Wellbeing, United Arab Emirates, accessed January 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>However, further opportunities exist, on a systematic basis, for employers and governments across the region. This article explores the status of employee health and well-being, and includes data and insights that GCC leaders could consider using to inform strategies and actions to address the causes of ill health among employees.</p>

well-being for all</a>, most employees are likely to experience some symptoms of poor mental health and well-being at some point during their working years.<span That figure is closer to one in three among GCC employees surveyed, a finding that is consistent with other studies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8654cf58-fc96-4329-b9cd-a8f4cc795775"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8654cf58-fc96-4329-b9cd-a8f4cc795775" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Turki Alqarni et al., Prevalence of stress, burnout, and job satisfaction among mental healthcare professionals in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, PloS One, April 27, 2022, Volume 17, Number 4; Shatha Ali et al., The prevalence of burnout among interns in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and its relation to engaging in unethical behaviors, <em>Middle East Current Psychiatry</em>, October 2021, Volume 28.</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, GCC respondents also reported higher levels of distress at the time of the survey, which may be a precursor to burnout symptoms (55 percent, compared with 32 percent).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b73bba7a-9034-4ee7-b3e3-08625e9cdfb2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b73bba7a-9034-4ee7-b3e3-08625e9cdfb2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Maria Frederika Agnes van Hoffen, Stress and sickness absence, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>More than twice the percentage of GCC respondents report an intent to leave their jobs, compared with employees globally (36 percent, compared with 16 percent). Although the great attrition<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2e11e6b7-4ce6-4199-af99-db828c0af242"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2e11e6b7-4ce6-4199-af99-db828c0af242" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Aaron De Smet, Bonnie Dowling, Marino Mugayar-Baldocchi, and Bill Schaninger, <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/great-attrition-or-great-attraction-the-choice-is-yours">Great Attrition or Great Attraction? The choice is yours</a>, McKinsey, September 8, 2021. </span></span></span></a></span> is a global phenomenon, with factors that include employees not feeling valued, some GCC-specific factors could be exacerbating intent to leave.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="07658d3f-b145-454e-a2b9-3313926ce106"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="07658d3f-b145-454e-a2b9-3313926ce106" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Philippe Fargues, Nasra M. Shah, and Imco Brouwer, <em>Working and living conditions of low-income migrant workers in the hospitality and construction sectors in the United Arab Emirates</em>, Gulf Labour Markets and Migration, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> Specific to the region, variable factors can include sponsorship requirements for expatriates, or competition for local talent. </p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/better%20health%20among%20middle%20eastern%20employees%20can%20start%20with%20awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Symptoms of depression, anxiety, and distress were all higher than the global average among Gulf Cooperation Council survey respondents." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/better%20health%20among%20middle%20eastern%20employees%20can%20start%20with%20awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>In our survey, GCC employees who report experiencing high levels of toxic behavior at work are seven times more likely to experience burnout symptoms, compared with a global average of eight times more likely (see sidebar What is toxic workplace behavior?). In turn, respondents experiencing burnout symptoms are four times more likely to report that they intend to leave their employers in the next three to six months (compared with a global average of six times). While GCC respondents show a similar overall pattern to the global findings, they are less likely to show signs of burnout in response to toxic behavior and are less likely to leave.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4a481e73-ce68-447a-8950-83b1d66716bb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4a481e73-ce68-447a-8950-83b1d66716bb" compensation alone.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" <p>Almost half of respondents say the time they dedicate to their jobs curbs the time they have to care for physical health. Some respondents say that underlying behaviors, such as inadequate sleep or unhealthy eating, affects their physical health. </p>
<p>Along with work-related challenges, rapid socioeconomic development is one of several factors in the region that has contributed to a more sedentary lifestyle (among the highest in the world) and a concurrent rise in obesity and diabetes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="49cae5a8-d335-4569-a670-0a04ef6bf247"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="49cae5a8-d335-4569-a670-0a04ef6bf247" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Zlatko Nikoloski et al., Obesity in the Middle East, in <em>Metabolic Syndrome: A Comprehensive Textbook</em>, New York, NY: Springer, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span> Chronic diseases are now the leading causes of morbidity and mortality.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f64e982a-6932-4b34-9ffc-700ff877b9c1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f64e982a-6932-4b34-9ffc-700ff877b9c1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Obesity in the Middle East, <em>Metabolic Syndrome</em>, 2015; Aly Bernard Khalil, Diabesity in the Arabian Gulf: Challenges and opportunities, <em>Oman Medical Journal</em>, July 2018, Volume 33, Issue 4.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/better%20health%20among%20middle%20eastern%20employees%20can%20start%20with%20awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="About 42 percent of survey respondents reported experiencing physical pain that prevents them from doing some work-related activities." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/better%20health%20among%20middle%20eastern%20employees%20can%20start%20with%20awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Insight 5: Locally born respondents report higher rates of poor mental and physical health than expatriate employees</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>Expatriate employees surveyed<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d2cfb988-e794-4d34-a6ee-fabcc968428d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d2cfb988-e794-4d34-a6ee-fabcc968428d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Respondents are classified as locally born if the question What is your nationality? has been answered with either Saudi, Qatari, Kuwaiti, or Emirati in the respective countries; otherwise, respondents have been classified as expatriates.</span></span></span></a></span> report symptoms of depression, anxiety, and burnout at rates that are at or close to global averages, whereas locally born respondents report higher rates of depression, anxiety, distress, and burnout. Furthermore, almost 40 percent of locally born workers say they expect to leave their current organization within the next six months. Some research has suggested that anonymity in the survey may allow locally born workers to acknowledge their mental-health challenges without concerns about deep-rooted stigma.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a999c81c-b4c2-4646-8954-cb415c5cd045"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a999c81c-b4c2-4646-8954-cb415c5cd045" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Yara M. Asi, Increasing awareness of mental health needs in Arab populations, Arab Center Washington DC, March 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>
</p>
<p>Physical health is also stronger for expatriates, with 27 percent reporting symptoms of physical pain (compared with 47 percent for locally born respondents). This may be linked to expatriate workers being younger than locally born workers and/or having to pass health-screening tests from host countries. </p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/better%20health%20among%20middle%20eastern%20employees%20can%20start%20with%20awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Locally born employees report significantly higher rates in both mental- and physical-health domains." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/better%20health%20among%20middle%20eastern%20employees%20can%20start%20with%20awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Targeted actions that could improve outcomes</h2>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>What is toxic workplace behavior?</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><strong>Toxic workplace behavior</strong> is interpersonal behavior that leads to employees feeling unvalued, belittled, or unsafe, such as unfair or demeaning treatment, noninclusive behavior, sabotaging, cutthroat competition, abusive management, and unethical behavior from leaders or coworkers. Selected questions from this dimension include agreement with the statements My manager ridicules me, I work with people who belittle my ideas, and My manager puts me down in front of others.</div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Actions, both preventive and reactive, taken by employers at three levelsorganizational, team, and individualcould help to improve employee health and well-being in the GCC region.</p>
<p>Governments also play an important role in fostering health and well-being and in creating an environment for society to flourish and organizations to act. They could consider measures to prevent overall damage to individuals and the system, while having the infrastructure to react if symptoms have already materialized, such as:</p>
<ul>
    <li>ensure health and well-being is on their agendas at every level, clarify their aspirations, and craft action plans to drive innovation and impact (for example, by following the WHOs guidelines for mental health at work<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4513909d-9196-4695-b4f0-878cf783f74c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4513909d-9196-4695-b4f0-878cf783f74c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Guidelines on mental health at work, WHO, September 28, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span>)</li>
    <li>boost awareness with an inspirational narrative (for example, a campaign reinforcing the importance of employee health) and foster dialogue to reduce stigma </li>
    <li>define regulatory standards for psychological health and safety in the workplace (for example, possible penalties for organizations that fail to comply) </li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The role of happiness</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Among respondents in this survey, </strong>the most reported complaint affecting social and spiritual health is a lack of happiness with amount of time spent on nonwork-related activities (9 percent
of respondents).</p>
<p>Happiness refers to agreement or strong agreement with the statement, I feel happy at work most of the time. Employees who rate themselves as happy at work are also significantly more likely to indicate they have strong relationships with others at work or feel an overall sense of purpose (correlates with happiness scores of 0.29 and 0.24, respectively).</p>
<p>Yet what is behind who feels happiness and why? While we found no immediate association between physical health and happiness, social and spiritual health seem to be associated with higher levels of happiness. It also appears correlated to having an especially strong sense of work purpose and satisfaction with coworker relationships.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bcc75e73-b370-4092-8792-d1eafeb7f6bb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bcc75e73-b370-4092-8792-d1eafeb7f6bb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Satisfaction refers to agreement or strong agreement and dissatisfaction refers to disagreement or strong disagreement with the statements I am satisfied with personal relationships at work or The work I do serves a greater purpose.</span></span></span></a></span> Interest in and examination of happiness in the region is steady: a 2015 report found that UAE, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia were the three happiest countries to work in the Middle East region,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9973b374-8537-461a-b622-3df358ed9d36"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9973b374-8537-461a-b622-3df358ed9d36" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Suhail Masri, The Middle Easts top three happiest countries to work in, Gulf Business, May 14, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span> while one ongoing research project looks at the effects of the UAE Happiness and Wellbeing policy implementation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f1efcb4c-638a-462e-a34c-0525a839d77d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f1efcb4c-638a-462e-a34c-0525a839d77d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Omneya Omar, Signing up for happiness: An exploratory study of workforce changes in the UAE market in response to the National Program for Happiness and Wellbeing, <em>Middle East Journal of Positive Psychology</em>, December 23, 2018, Volume 4, Issue 1. </span></span></span></a></span> </p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>For example, UAE has developed clear positioning and ambitions regarding 90 initiatives supporting its National Wellbeing Strategy.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0dd228d1-1143-495a-a118-38ceeaaeb6ac"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0dd228d1-1143-495a-a118-38ceeaaeb6ac" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">UAE National Wellbeing Strategy 2031, United Arab Emirates Government portal, accessed December 2022. </span></span></span></a></span> Among those are a Happiness and Wellbeing Policy Bundle, which sets guidelines and requirements for all groups in society; the Network of Happiness and Wellbeing chief officers working on developing programs promoting health and well-being at the workplace, where participants must achieve a Happiness and Wellbeing diploma; and the Global Dialogue for Happiness and Wellbeing raising overall awareness and fostering alignment among governments and organizations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2cd46e64-9db8-4029-bf21-7bec021baac4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2cd46e64-9db8-4029-bf21-7bec021baac4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Majid Al Futtaim achieves the WELL health-safety rating for its HQ and announces one of MENA regions largest WELL health-safety rating enrollments in the retail sector, WELL press release, June 29, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> (For more on happiness, see sidebar The role of happiness.)</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Digitally generated image of a tree inside glass containers on a blue background" src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/the%20secret%20to%20great%20health%20escaping%20the%20healthcare%20matrix/the-secret-to-great-health-1339038575-thumb-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>The secret to great health? Escaping the healthcare matrix</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/mhi/our-insights/the-secret-to-great-health-escaping-the-healthcare-matrix" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h2>Successful approaches maintain a few focus areas over time and encourage role modeling and sustained ownership by leaders</h2>
<p>Organizations can examine actions that drive employee health and well-being (see sidebar Organizations could take a systemic approach to improving employee mental health and well-being). Additionally, each employee can individually drive mental health and well-being. As illustrated by the examples above, this involves three common themes:</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Organizations could take a systemic approach to improving employee mental health and well-being</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>We suggest <a href="/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem">eight actions</a></strong> (exhibit) that will drive improvement in employee health and well-being. </p>
<p>For example, as part of its company-wide sustainability strategy, Dare today, change tomorrow, Majid al Futtaim has the ambition of creating healthy workplaces, underpinned by a new Healthy Workplaces Policy. This policy sets new standards for the design and amenities of physical workplaces, as well as corporate well-being programs and a WELL certification.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0dbc2316-1206-4ac7-9fae-f440120b1eae"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0dbc2316-1206-4ac7-9fae-f440120b1eae" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Omneya Omar, Signing up for happiness: An exploratory study of workforce changes in the UAE market in response to the National Program for Happiness and Wellbeing, <em>Middle East Journal of Positive Psychology</em>, December 23, 2018, Volume 4, Issue 1. </span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>As individuals, managers could be encouraged to take ownership of health and well-being with personalized and bite-sized interventions. As a result, they not only take care of their own health and well-being but also act as role models for people they lead. Interventions may include: </p>
<ul>
    <li>encouraging assessment of health across the four health dimensions via the latest real-time health measurements, set aspirations, and take steps to achieve them for themselves and their teams </li>
    <li>offering education related to individual health status (for example, via an integrated health platform) and highlighting that external support is offered</li>
    <li>starting small and staying focused, embedding one habit at a time to improve physical health (dedicate time for exercise, improve sleep hygiene), mental health (meditate, engage in meaningful activities), spiritual health (practice yoga, connect with a faith community), and social health (interact with peers, join local teams or interest groups)</li>
</ul>
<p>In addition to its top-down policies and precautionary measures implementing the highest health and safety standards for each individual, Aldar Properties fosters employee-driven initiatives leveraging advanced systems and technology. With a focus on providing remote working options, health offerings are highly digitized; employees have access to an online well-being platform and the ability to sign up for live sessions with health authority professionals.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="32d9b1a9-ae1f-425a-8250-ad88ff3248ef"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="32d9b1a9-ae1f-425a-8250-ad88ff3248ef" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Aldar supports nationwide efforts to protect health and wellbeing, UAE Today, December 22, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/better%20health%20among%20middle%20eastern%20employees%20can%20start%20with%20awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-exsidebar-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Eight key actions drive improvement in employee mental health and well-being." src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20health%20institute/our%20insights/better%20health%20among%20middle%20eastern%20employees%20can%20start%20with%20awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-exsidebar-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<ul>
    <li><em>First, start with a diagnosis. </em>Understanding the baseline can help choose how to prioritize which issues are the most pressing, and where to start in addressing them.</li>
    <li><em>Second, choose one or two health dimensions of focus and target goals and priorities based on the diagnostic.</em> What are the most impactful opportunities for change? What is the realistic vision for the well-being strategy, accounting for the constraints faced by an organization? For example, Majid al Futtaims focus on workplace involves expanding into different health arenas (for example, a biggest loser challenge to promote physical health).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a5a413c9-2a3b-4c49-b66e-8d89fbc99d7b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a5a413c9-2a3b-4c49-b66e-8d89fbc99d7b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Dare today, change tomorrow: Sustainability report 2017</em>, Majid Al Futtaim. </span></span></span></a></span> Similarly, individuals could consider ways to incorporate habits such as a daily active break or meditation. The goal is to experience fast successes before getting intimidated by time constraints or limited resources.</li>
    <li>
    <p><em>Third, leaders should role-model interventions, change ways of working from the ground up, and make a sustained commitment over time.</em> Early adopters on all levels help accelerate uptake intervention programs and can serve as ambassadors to raise awareness of health agendas and programs. For example, the UAE hosts the Global Dialogue for Happiness and Wellbeing to bring together experts from around the world to share best practices and expertise. Majid Al Futtaims WeCare representatives are based in each store and discuss professional and individual needs with their colleagues. The goal is not only to establish new standards of what good looks like but also to act as a multiplier for a shared overall benefit.</p>
    <p>On a societal and organizational level, leadership commitment plays a crucial role not only in terms of clear positioning but also in the actual doing. One example is a driver awareness campaign started by Ibrahim Al-Zubi, chief sustainability officer at Majid al Futtaim. The goal is to show a genuine purpose-driven change that rallies the society, the organization, and all employees behind a shared goal.</p>
    </li>
    <li><em>Finally, well-being metrics need to be linked to employee performance and organizational outcomes, and relentlessly tracked.</em> At a governmental level, societal impact of initiatives also needs to be measured and tracked.</li>
</ul>
<p>Making the investment to improve employee health and well-being is not easyand often means committing to a journey over time. This can lead to an upward trajectory in sustained individual and organizational performance with an employer, and in the communities and societies in which they operate.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/mona-hammami">Mona Hammami</a></strong> is a partner in McKinseys Abu Dhabi office; <strong>Ahmed Osman</strong> is an associate partner in the Dubai office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/mischa-zielke">Mischa Zielke</a></strong> is a partner; <strong>Vanessa Schneider</strong> is an associate partner in the Frankfurt office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Aarati Ajay, Jacqueline Brassey, Erica Coe, Amadeo Di Lodovico, Neil Fisher, Renata Giarola, Sriparna Gogoi, Brad Herbig, Sina Israel, Barbara Jeffery, and Roxy Merkand health among Middle Eastern employees can start with awareness"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Improving employee health in the Middle East"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"A survey of workers in four Middle Eastern countries provides a baseline for understanding the state of employee health and informing strategies to improve outcomes."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"A survey of workers in four Middle Eastern countries provides a baseline for understanding the state of employee health and how to improve outcomes."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-01-30T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePrevious McKinsey research\u003c/strong\u003e has shown that for the past century or more, improvements in health have not only delivered immense social benefits[[Footnote 1]] but also served as a powerful catalyst for economic growth by expanding the labor force and boosting productivity.[[Footnote 2]] When employers invest in the health and well-being of their workforce, they have often made gains in productivity and reduced attrition.[[Footnote 3]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCountries in the Middle East and around the globe are increasingly embracing a modern definition of health that encompasses not just the absence of physical illness but an all-encompassing state of equilibrium between a person\u0026rsquo;s internal and external environments. This broader definition includes four dimensions: physical, mental, social, and spiritual health.[[Footnote 4]] \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn early fall 2022, the McKinsey Health Institute surveyed more than four thousand employees in four Middle Eastern countries that are part of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC)\u0026mdash;Kuwait, United Arab Emirates (UAE), Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, and Qatar\u0026mdash;to understand the state of employee health in the region (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;About the survey and what we measured\u0026rdquo;). \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article summarizes what our respondents told us about the state of their health as they saw it, namely, that:\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eTwo-thirds of GCC respondents reported symptoms of poor mental health and well-being, or had a mental-health condition diagnosis.[[Footnote 5]] \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOne in three GCC respondents reported burnout symptoms. Many also reported struggles with physical health conditions, but better social and spiritual health, with different patterns among demographic groups. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThree-quarters of GCC respondents reported being happy at work, which appeared to be correlated with employees listing a sense of purpose in their work and in their relationships at work.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome targeted actions by GCC countries point to growing recognition of the importance of promoting employee health and well-being. For example, the UAE has been an early adopter in integrating employee health and well-being into its governmental agenda by setting up the National Program for Happiness and Wellbeing.[[Footnote 6]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, further opportunities exist, on a systematic basis, for employers and governments across the region. This article explores the status of employee health and well-being, and includes data and insights that GCC leaders could consider using to inform strategies and actions to address the causes of ill health among employees.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n[[Story 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eTargeted actions that could improve outcomes\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Sidebar 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eActions, both preventive and reactive, taken by employers at three levels\u0026mdash;organizational, team, and individual\u0026mdash;could help to improve employee health and well-being in the GCC region.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGovernments also play an important role in fostering health and well-being and in creating an environment for society to flourish and organizations to act. They could consider measures to prevent overall damage to individuals and the system, while having the infrastructure to react if symptoms have already materialized, such as:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eensure health and well-being is on their agendas at every level, clarify their aspirations, and craft action plans to drive innovation and impact (for example, by following the WHO\u0026rsquo;s guidelines for mental health at work[[Footnote 7]])\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eboost awareness with an inspirational narrative (for example, a campaign reinforcing the importance of employee health) and foster dialogue to reduce stigma \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003edefine regulatory standards for psychological health and safety in the workplace (for example, possible penalties for organizations that fail to comply) \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, UAE has developed clear positioning and ambitions regarding 90 initiatives supporting its National Wellbeing Strategy.[[Footnote 8]] Among those are a Happiness and Wellbeing Policy Bundle, which sets guidelines and requirements for all groups in society; the Network of Happiness and Wellbeing chief officers working on developing programs promoting health and well-being at the workplace, where participants must achieve a Happiness and Wellbeing diploma; and the Global Dialogue for Happiness and Wellbeing raising overall awareness and fostering alignment among governments and organizations.[[Footnote 9]] (For more on happiness, see sidebar \u0026ldquo;The role of happiness.\u0026rdquo;)\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1Up 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eSuccessful approaches maintain a few focus areas over time and encourage role modeling and sustained ownership by leaders\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOrganizations can examine actions that drive employee health and well-being (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Organizations could take a systemic approach to improving employee mental health and well-being\u0026rdquo;). Additionally, each employee can individually drive mental health and well-being. As illustrated by the examples above, this involves three common themes:\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 3]]\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFirst, start with a diagnosis. \u003c/em\u003eUnderstanding the baseline can help choose how to prioritize which issues are the most pressing, and where to start in addressing them.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSecond, choose one or two health dimensions of focus and target goals and priorities based on the diagnostic.\u003c/em\u003e What are the most impactful opportunities for change? What is the realistic vision for the well-being strategy, accounting for the constraints faced by an organization? For example, Majid al Futtaim\u0026rsquo;s focus on workplace involves expanding into different health arenas (for example, a \u0026ldquo;biggest loser\u0026rdquo; challenge to promote physical health).[[Footnote 10]] Similarly, individuals could consider ways to incorporate habits such as a daily active break or meditation. The goal is to experience fast successes before getting intimidated by time constraints or limited resources.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThird, leaders should role-model interventions, change ways of working from the ground up, and make a sustained commitment over time.\u003c/em\u003e Early adopters on all levels help accelerate uptake intervention programs and can serve as ambassadors to raise awareness of health agendas and programs. For example, the UAE hosts the \u0026ldquo;Global Dialogue for Happiness and Wellbeing\u0026rdquo; to bring together experts from around the world to share best practices and expertise. Majid Al Futtaim\u0026rsquo;s \u0026ldquo;WeCare\u0026rdquo; representatives are based in each store and discuss professional and individual needs with their colleagues. The goal is not only to establish new standards of what good looks like but also to act as a multiplier for a shared overall benefit.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eOn a societal and organizational level, leadership commitment plays a crucial role not only in terms of clear positioning but also in the actual doing. One example is a driver awareness campaign started by Ibrahim Al-Zu\u0026rsquo;bi, chief sustainability officer at Majid al Futtaim. The goal is to show a genuine purpose-driven change that rallies the society, the organization, and all employees behind a shared goal.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFinally, well-being metrics need to be linked to employee performance and organizational outcomes, and relentlessly tracked.\u003c/em\u003e At a governmental level, societal impact of initiatives also needs to be measured and tracked.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMaking the investment to improve employee health and well-being is not easy\u0026mdash;and often means committing to a journey over time. This can lead to an upward trajectory in sustained individual and organizational performance with an employer, and in the communities and societies in which they operate.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":{"name":"McKinsey Health Institute","displayName":"McKinsey Health Institute","title":{"value":"McKinsey Health Institute"},"relatedlinks":{"url":"/mhi/overview"},"landinglinks":{"jsonValue":{"value":[]}}}},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-01-30T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/adding-years-to-life-and-life-to-years\"\u003eAdding years to life and life to years\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, McKinsey, March 29, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/prioritizing-health-a-prescription-for-prosperity\"\u003ePrioritizing health: A prescription for prosperity\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;
