current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe McKinsey Health Institute\u003c/strong\u003e conducted a survey in four GCC countries in August and September 2022. This survey involved more than four thousand employees in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, and Qatar.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe assessed a range of health outcomes (mental, physical, social, and spiritual), business outcomes (with a focus on intent to leave), and workplace factors (with a strong focus on toxic workplace behaviors) in our survey.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHealth outcomes assessed in our survey included:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMental health: \u003c/strong\u003eAn employee\u0026rsquo;s cognitive, behavioral, and emotional state of being. Mental health is needed for an individual to understand and interact with the world through memory and language. Mental health allows us to experience joy, direct anger, limit harmful, impulsive behavior, and avoid serious depressive episodes. Mentally healthy individuals have the resilience to cope with normal stresses and adverse events while maintaining a positive and realistic sense of self.\u003c/em\u003e[[Footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWithin this survey, we looked at four subfacets:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBurnout symptoms:\u003c/em\u003e An employee\u0026rsquo;s experience of extreme tiredness, reduced ability to regulate cognitive and emotional processes, and mental distancing (Burnout Assessment Tool).[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDistress:\u003c/em\u003e An employee experiencing a negative stress response, often involving negative affect and physiological reactivity (4DSQ Distress Screener).[[Footnote 3]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDepression symptoms: \u003c/em\u003eAn employee having little interest or pleasure in doing things, and feeling down, depressed, or hopeless (PHQ-2 Screener).[[Footnote 4]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAnxiety symptoms:\u003c/em\u003e An employee\u0026rsquo;s feelings of nervousness, anxiousness, or being on edge, and not being able to stop or control worrying (GAD-2 Screener).[[Footnote 5]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePhysical health: \u003c/strong\u003eThe extent to which an employee can competently perform physical tasks and activities without substantial discomfort. It includes the capacity to move through the environment in which one lives with confidence and independence and to control one\u0026rsquo;s interactions with the physical world via fine-motor control. Employees with good physical health have sharp sensory capacities with keen senses of touch, vision, hearing, taste, and smell. Physically healthy employees are full of energy and vitality, free from the twin scourges of debilitating pain or fatigue, as per the World Health Organization (WHO).\u003c/em\u003e[[Footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this survey, we used a self-developed tool modifying questions from the WHO\u0026rsquo;s 2012 quality of life assessment, looking at:[[Footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eif the stress from respondents\u0026rsquo; jobs cause them to engage in unhealthy behaviors (for example, inadequate nutrition, lack of physical activity, lack of sleep)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eif respondents are self-reporting physical symptoms (experiencing physical pain that is preventing them from doing what they need to do at work)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSocial health: \u003c/strong\u003eRepresents an employee\u0026rsquo;s ability to build healthy, nurturing, genuine, and supportive relationships. Employees in good social health have the capacity to form meaningful connections with others, to both receive and provide social support. Social health gives employees a strong sense of belonging to a community.\u003c/em\u003e[[Footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this survey, we used a self-developed tool modifying questions from the WHO\u0026rsquo;s 2012 quality of life assessment, looking at a range of social factors (including personal relationships, participating in group activities, time spent on nonwork activities and important people in their life).[[Footnote 9]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSpiritual health:\u003c/strong\u003e Enables people to integrate meaning in their lives. Spiritually healthy people have a strong sense of purpose, belonging, or identity, which can correlate to better health.\u003c/em\u003e[[Footnote 10]]\u003cem\u003eThey feel a broad sense of connection to something larger than themselves, whether to a community, a calling, or a form of divinity. Spiritual health helps people feel rooted and mindful in the present moment.\u003c/em\u003e[[Footnote 11]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this survey, we used a self-developed tool modifying questions from Spiritual Health and Life Orientation Measure, 2010, and the Work and Meaning Inventory, 2012, looking at a range of spiritual factors (including sense of fulfilling a greater purpose, living in harmony, and feeling energized by work).[[Footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWork-related outcomes and factors assessed in our survey included:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIntent to leave:\u003c/strong\u003e In this survey, we used a self-developed tool to assess an employee\u0026rsquo;s desire to leave the organization in which they are currently employed in the next three to six months.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eToxic workplace behavior: \u003c/strong\u003eIn this survey, we used a self-developed tool to assess an employees\u0026rsquo; experience of interpersonal behavior that leads them to feel unvalued, belittled, or unsafe, such as unfair or demeaning treatment, noninclusive behavior, sabotaging, cutthroat competition, abusive management, and unethical behavior from leaders or coworkers.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe analysis of share of respondents reporting at least one mental-health challenge was determined by aggregating respondents reporting having a mental-health diagnosis, now or in the past; reporting to have sought or considered treatment for a mental-health condition; or having listed at least one of the following: symptoms of anxiety, burnout, depression, or distress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConsideration of cross-country surveys\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs cited in previous global pieces about health, such as \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/in-sickness-and-in-health-how-health-is-perceived-around-the-world\"\u003eIn sickness and in health: How health is perceived around the world\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a range of cultural and methodological factors can influence respondents\u0026rsquo; answers to survey questions. These factors include, but are not limited to, language and word association, number ranges, comprehension issues, and attitudes toward taking surveys. It is important to note that comparisons between respondents in different countries are not only due to differences in attitudes and/or behaviors between respondents but also reflect response styles that are specific to cultural and geographic locations. Any insights drawn from cross-country comparisons should be interpreted with consideration of these multiple influences to survey responses.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"About the survey and what we measured"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSilvana Galderisi et al., \u0026ldquo;Toward a new definition of mental health,\u0026rdquo; While we found no immediate association between physical health and happiness, social and spiritual health seem to be associated with higher levels of happiness. It also appears correlated to having an especially strong sense of work purpose and satisfaction with coworker relationships.[[Footnote 1]] Interest in and examination of happiness in the region is steady: a 2015 report found that UAE, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia were the three happiest countries to work in the Middle East region,[[Footnote 2]] while one ongoing research project looks at the effects of the UAE Happiness and Wellbeing policy implementation.[[Footnote 3]] \u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The role of happiness"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Satisfaction\u0026rdquo; or \u0026ldquo;The work I do serves a greater purpose.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSuhail Masri, \u0026ldquo;The Middle East\u0026rsquo;s top three happiest countries to work in,\u0026rdquo; Gulf Business, May 14, 2015.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOmneya Omar, \u0026ldquo;Signing up for happiness: An exploratory study of workforce changes in the UAE market in response to the National Program for Happiness and Wellbeing,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eMiddle East Journal of Positive Psychology\u003c/em\u003e, December 23, 2018, Volume 4, Issue 1. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"3"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWe suggest \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem\"\u003eeight actions\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e (exhibit) that will drive improvement in employee health and well-being. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, as part of its company-wide sustainability strategy, \u0026ldquo;Dare today, change tomorrow,\u0026rdquo; Majid al Futtaim has the ambition of creating healthy workplaces, underpinned by a new Healthy Workplaces Policy. This policy sets new standards for the design and amenities of physical workplaces, as well as corporate well-being programs and a \u0026ldquo;WELL\u0026rdquo; certification.[[Footnote 1]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs individuals, managers could be encouraged to take ownership of health and well-being with personalized and bite-sized interventions. As a result, they not only take care of their own health and well-being but also act as role models for people they lead. Interventions may include: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eencouraging assessment of health across the four health dimensions via the latest real-time health measurements, set aspirations, and take steps to achieve them for themselves and their teams \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eoffering education related to individual health status (for example, via an integrated health platform) and highlighting that external support is offered\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003estarting small and staying focused, embedding one habit at a time to improve physical health (dedicate time for exercise, improve sleep hygiene), mental health (meditate, engage in meaningful activities), spiritual health (practice yoga, connect with a faith community), and social health (interact with peers, join local teams or interest groups)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to its top-down policies and precautionary measures implementing the highest health and safety standards for each individual, Aldar Properties fosters employee-driven initiatives leveraging advanced systems and technology. With a focus on providing remote working options, health offerings are highly digitized; employees have access to an online well-being platform and the ability to sign up for live sessions with health authority professionals.[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit sidebar]]"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Organizations could take a systemic approach to improving employee mental health and well-being"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOmneya Omar, \u0026ldquo;Signing up for happiness: An exploratory study of workforce changes in the UAE market in response to the National Program for Happiness and Wellbeing,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eMiddle East Journal of Positive Psychology\u003c/em\u003e, December 23, 2018, Volume 4, Issue 1. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Aldar supports nationwide efforts to protect health and wellbeing,\u0026rdquo; UAE Today, December 22, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"4"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cstrong\u003eToxic workplace behavior\u003c/strong\u003e is interpersonal behavior that leads to employees feeling unvalued, belittled, or unsafe, such as unfair or demeaning treatment, noninclusive behavior, sabotaging, cutthroat competition, abusive management, and unethical behavior from leaders or coworkers. Selected questions from this dimension include agreement with the statements \u0026ldquo;My manager ridicules me,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;I work with people who belittle my ideas,\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;My manager puts me down in front of others.\u0026rdquo;"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"What is toxic workplace behavior?"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}}]},"globalsidebar":{"results":[]},"video":{"results":[]},"scrollycontainer":{"results":[]},"bespokeinteractive":{"results":[]},"storycontainer":{"results":[{"id":"1BAB66E808F44F729A50B060A7169A50","mediaID":{"value":"1"},"collapseTopSpace":{"boolValue":false},"collapseBottomSpace":{"boolValue":false},"desktopTextColumnWidth":{"targetItem":null},"children":{"results":[{"id":"95B339BA8C5543FDA1A47152A5F49A01","name":"Story 1","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Insight 1: More than 60 percent of GCC respondents say they have experienced mental- and physical-health challenges at some point in their lives"},"description":{"value":"Physical and mental health are intimately entwined. Mental health, like physical health, exists along a continuum from optimal health to poor health. As we described in our article \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/present-company-included-prioritizing-mental-health-and-well-being-for-all\"\u003ePresent company included, prioritizing mental health and well-being for all\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; most employees are likely to experience some symptoms of poor mental health and well-being at some point during their working years.[[Footnote 1]] Sixty-six percent of GCC respondents said they have experienced at least one mental-health challenge at some point in their lives\u0026mdash;a figure slightly higher compared with other global research.[[Footnote 2]] This is proportional to physical-health challenges, where more than two-thirds also report at least one symptom of poor physical health."},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/better health among middle eastern employees can start with awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex1.svgz","alt":"The majority of Gulf Cooperation Council survey respondents said that they had experienced mental- and physical-health challenges.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eJulia Anas and Kelly Greenwood, \u0026ldquo;It\u0026rsquo;s a new era for mental health at work,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eHarvard Business Review\u003c/em\u003e, October 4, 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/present-company-included-prioritizing-mental-health-and-well-being-for-all\"\u003ePresent company included: Prioritizing mental health and well-being for all\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; McKinsey, October 10, 2022; \u0026ldquo;It\u0026rsquo;s a new era for mental health at work,\u0026rdquo; October 4, 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"607B38B9D17C44E986BA3BECCB8A10BC","name":"Story 2","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Insight 2: Anxiety, depression, and distress symptoms are all high among GCC respondents, reflecting a global trend"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eGlobally, one in four respondents are reporting burnout symptoms, which is correlated with poor mental health. That figure is closer to one in three among GCC employees surveyed, a finding that is consistent with other studies.[[Footnote 1]] Additionally, GCC respondents also reported higher levels of distress at the time of the survey, which may be a precursor to burnout symptoms (55 percent, compared with 32 percent).[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore than twice the percentage of GCC respondents report an intent to leave their jobs, compared with employees globally (36 percent, compared with 16 percent). Although the great attrition[[Footnote 3]] is a global phenomenon, with factors that include employees not feeling valued, some GCC-specific factors could be exacerbating intent to leave.[[Footnote 4]] Specific to the region, variable factors can include sponsorship requirements for expatriates, or competition for local talent. \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/better health among middle eastern employees can start with awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex2.svgz","alt":"Symptoms of depression, anxiety, and distress were all higher than the global average among Gulf Cooperation Council survey respondents.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eTurki Alqarni et al., \u0026ldquo;Prevalence of stress, burnout, and job satisfaction among mental healthcare professionals in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia,\u0026rdquo; PloS One, April 27, 2022, Volume 17, Number 4; Shatha Ali et al., \u0026ldquo;The prevalence of burnout among interns in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and its relation to engaging in unethical behaviors,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eMiddle East Current Psychiatry\u003c/em\u003e, October 2021, Volume 28.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMaria Frederika Agnes van Hoffen, \u0026ldquo;Stress and sickness absence,\u0026rdquo; Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAaron De Smet, Bonnie Dowling, Marino Mugayar-Baldocchi, and Bill Schaninger, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/great-attrition-or-great-attraction-the-choice-is-yours\"\u003e\u0026lsquo;Great Attrition\u0026rsquo; or \u0026lsquo;Great Attraction\u0026rsquo;? The choice is yours\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; McKinsey, September 8, 2021. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ePhilippe Fargues, Nasra M. Shah, and Imco Brouwer, \u003cem\u003eWorking and living conditions of low-income migrant workers in the hospitality and construction sectors in the United Arab Emirates\u003c/em\u003e, Gulf Labour Markets and Migration, 2019.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"EB16F92AEFDB434DAD990471E3DCC1A0","name":"Story 3","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Insight 3: Symptoms of burnout and intent to leave are often driven by toxic behavior at work"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eGlobally, employees reporting high levels of toxic behavior at work are more likely to experience burnout, leading to an increased intention to quit.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn our survey, GCC employees who report experiencing high levels of toxic behavior at work are seven times more likely to experience burnout symptoms, compared with a global average of eight times more likely (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;What is toxic workplace behavior?\u0026rdquo;). In turn, respondents experiencing burnout symptoms are four times more likely to report that they intend to leave their employers in the next three to six months (compared with a global average of six times). While GCC respondents show a similar overall pattern to the global findings, they are less likely to show signs of burnout in response to toxic behavior and are less likely to leave.[[Footnote 1]] Recent data has indicated that toxic culture is the single largest predictor of resignation during the Great Attrition and ten times more predictive than compensation alone.[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/better health among middle eastern employees can start with awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex3.svgz","alt":"Employees reporting high levels of toxic behavior at work are more likely to experience burnout, leading to an increased intention to quit.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/addressing-employee-burnout-are-you-solving-the-right-problem\"\u003eAddressing employee burnout: Are you solving the right problem?\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; McKinsey, May 27, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCharles Sull et al., \u0026ldquo;Toxic culture is driving the Great Resignation,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eMIT Sloan Management Review\u003c/em\u003e, January 11, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"A63212BAE3DE4BA68BF950F500FAC318","name":"Story 4","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Insight 4: Poor physical health affects some respondents ability to work"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eOverall, an average of about 42 percent of respondents report experiencing physical pain that prevents them from doing some work-related activities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlmost half of respondents say the time they dedicate to their jobs curbs the time they have to care for physical health. Some respondents say that underlying behaviors, such as inadequate sleep or unhealthy eating, affects their physical health. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlong with work-related challenges, rapid socioeconomic development is one of several factors in the region that has contributed to a more sedentary lifestyle (among the highest in the world) and a concurrent rise in obesity and diabetes.[[Footnote 1]] Chronic diseases are now the leading causes of morbidity and mortality.[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/better health among middle eastern employees can start with awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex4.svgz","alt":"About 42 percent of survey respondents reported experiencing physical pain that prevents them from doing some work-related activities.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eZlatko Nikoloski et al., \u0026ldquo;Obesity in the Middle East,\u0026rdquo; in \u003cem\u003eMetabolic Syndrome: A Comprehensive Textbook\u003c/em\u003e, New York, NY: Springer, 2015.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Obesity in the Middle East,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eMetabolic Syndrome\u003c/em\u003e, 2015; Aly Bernard Khalil, \u0026ldquo;Diabesity in the Arabian Gulf: Challenges and opportunities,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eOman Medical Journal\u003c/em\u003e, July 2018, Volume 33, Issue 4.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"DFB66F766F324CE9A0DA8EF7E1086BC4","name":"Story 5","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Insight 5: Locally born respondents report higher rates of poor mental and physical health than expatriate employees"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eExpatriate employees surveyed[[Footnote 1]] report symptoms of depression, anxiety, and burnout at rates that are at or close to global averages, whereas locally born respondents report higher rates of depression, anxiety, distress, and burnout. Furthermore, almost 40 percent of locally born workers say they expect to leave their current organization within the next six months. Some research has suggested that anonymity in the survey may allow locally born workers to acknowledge their mental-health challenges without concerns about deep-rooted stigma.[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePhysical health is also stronger for expatriates, with 27 percent reporting symptoms of physical pain (compared with 47 percent for locally born respondents). This may be linked to expatriate workers being younger than locally born workers and/or having to pass health-screening tests from host countries. \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/better health among middle eastern employees can start with awareness/svgz-middleeastmentalhealth-ex5.svgz","alt":"Locally born employees report significantly higher rates in both mental- and physical-health domains.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eRespondents are classified as locally born if the question \u0026ldquo;What is your nationality?\u0026rdquo; has been answered with either Saudi, Qatari, Kuwaiti, or Emirati in the respective countries; otherwise, respondents have been classified as expatriates.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eYara M.
